resources.string: Welcome to TGuide!\nUse this space to keep your notes.
Use this space to keep any notes you may have.
Click on the button below to create a reminder!

Welcome to TGuide! The TGuide Team hopes this app can be a way to help you. When you enter the app, click on the button in the top left of the screen to begin exploring what this app has to offer. Visit the FAQ page for a serious of commonly asked questions and for a couple other resources that may help you! Please note that TGuide is only meant to aid you in manage your condition and is not responsible for any missed appointments or other issues that may arise when using this app. Lets get started!

Turner Syndrome (TS) is a condition that affects only girls and women. Most people have 23 pairs of chromosomes, with 1 pair being sex chromosomes. Most males have an X and Y sex chromosome and most females have two X chromosomes. In TS, there is an absence of all or part of the second X chromosome in some or all of the cells of the body.
Are there different types of Turner Syndrome?

There are multiple types of TS. Females who are completely missing an X chromosome have "classic" TS. Others are missing only part of the second X chromosome or have structural rearrangements of the chromosome. In some females, only some cells are missing the X chromosome, known as a mosaic karyotype. Knowing your type is important because each type is associated with different health issues.
Why is it important to know if someone has Turner Syndrome?

Missing part of or all of one X chromosome is associated with a range of health, development, social and learning challenges which affects females with TS to different extends. It is important to diagnosis TS as early as possible so that your health care provider can determine whether you have health issues that need to be treated or watched.

TS is not a disease, but a genetic condition that is associated with a range of health concerns. TS is not directly treated by a health care provider, but the individual health concerns that arise are monitored and treated. New medical developments allow women with TS who are interested in starting a family seek the help of an obstetrician who specializes in-vitro fertilization. A girl with TS may get growth horomone under the supervision of a pediartric endocrinologist.

TGuide is an app to help you manage your condition. It provides a framework to help you keep track of when to schedule appointments. Please note that TGuide is only meant to aid you in managing your condition and is not responsible for any missed appointments or other issues that may arise when using this app.
Why should I complete the checklist?
Managing a chronic condition can be difficult. Completing a checklist every couple of months can help you stay on track and see how you are doing.

The surveillance times outline when you see your physcian or other health care provider. The surveillance times table provides you with place to keep track of when you need to make appointments and will remind you when you are due!
I keep getting reminders every few months, can I get rid of them?
Unfortunately not, they are meant to remind you to fill out your checklist to help you keep track of how you are doing!
Where can I go for more information?

Great question!; 

To learn more about the Turner Society of Canada and the resources it has visit; www.turnersyndrome.ca 

A great place to learn about sexual health is; www.sexualityandu.ca 

Most importantly, your health care provider can be a great resource for any questions you may have!

Of course, ff you are interested in providing feedback or have any questions/concerns about TGuide, please feel free to email us at contacttguide@gmail.com or leave a comment on the app store. We are always looking for new ways to improve the app to better help you! \n If you have any questions about the Turner Society of Canada or other questions/concerns, please contact info@turnersyndrome.ca.

Reflection and meditation can help to reduce stress and anxiety. It is a great way to reflect on your daily life. Try to find a quite room and take a few minutes out of your day for yourself. Some questions to think about are: 
	 - How have you been doing recently? 
	 - Are you taking care of yourself physically? 
	 - What about mentally? 
	 - Do you feel stressed? How come? 
	 - Do you feel supported? 
	 - Do changes need to be made in your life? 
	 - Are you content? 

Try using the audio as a guide to help you with your reflection and meditation practice.

Use this space as a way to keep track of when you need to schedule appointments. Just click on the appointment and enter when your appointment is or was. The text will turn red when it is time to book another appointment and you will also receive a reminder! \n\nYou can download a PDF version of the table with a full description of the tests below.
Time to book your physical exam!
Go to surveillance times for more information.
Time for your bone density exam!
I have Turner Syndrome and I am at risk of Aortic Dissection. I have:
To check bicupsid aortic valve please type in;
To check aortic coarctation please type in;
To check high blood pressure please type in;

- Sudden severe chest or upper back pain 
- Shortness of breath, difficulty speaking 
- Dizzy, weak, sweaty, anxious, pale 
- Fast pulse

Females with Turner Syndrome have an increased likelihood of an aortic dissection which can be life threatening. If you are experiencing the aortic dissection symptoms then present to the emergency department immediately and present this card to help the emergency room staff to help guide your treatment. It is also best to keep a physical, paper card with this information on you as well.
"Contacts permissions are needed for providing email completions."
